When I expressed my inability to give so much money, Singh said me that I should give Rs 3,000 to him as the first installment and said that I should give remaining money later,” he added.

Upadhyay did not want to bribe therefore, he lodged a complaint with the ACB. Inspector Misir Oraon of the ACB investigated the case and found Upadhyay’s complaint correct. After this, based on the written application of Upadhyay the investigation report of Inspector Misir Oraon, ACB Ranchi police station recorded the case number 04/2020 on March 17 as the primary accused ASI Mithilesh Prasad Singh, who was originally from Simri Village in Saharsa district of Bihar.

In an another case, based on the written report of Nikunj Das resident of Chaibasa, a team of ACB officials arrested Field Supervisor of Agriculture Department, Chaibasa, Kumar Gaurav, from Jamshedpur while taking Rs 40,000 bribe.

Title: CCL to frame SOP to ensure safe workplaces for all: CMD
Article:
Central Coalfields Limited (CCL), a subsidiary of Coal India, will draft a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to ensure safe workplaces for all as the nation is witnessing a rise in Corona virus cases.

Chairman-cum-Managing Director (CMD) Gopal Singh asked to set up a core group at CCL headquarters for framing SOP, a full-proof mechanism to check the spread of the deadly virus. He also talked about the importance of 'Social Distancing' and urged the employees to raise the awareness level and follow steps undertaken by the government to avoid infection from such virus, which is transmitted through water droplets.

On Wednesday, an awareness programme was organized at CCL headquarter in the State Capital in which CMD CCL Singh, Director (Technical and Operations) VK Srivastava, CMS CCL Dr CP Dham, former CMS CCL- Dr Rakesh Arya and Dr RR Sinha, former CMS, Gandhinagar Hospital Dr BMK Sinha, CMS, Gandhinagar Dr Manjushree Singh, CMS Gandhingar Dr BKL Chowhan, Dr VK Singh, General Managers and HODs from headquarters and others were present. CMS, CCL Dr. CP Dham informed that the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has issued various guidelines to check spread of the Corona virus. He also informed that isolated six beds have been created atop of Jan Arogya Kendra, Gandhingar Colony to treat such if required. He further informed that the employees of CCL are being sensitised through posters and other means.

In the guidelines, Ministry has asked citizens to avoid group gathering, periodic hand hygiene, unnecessary public transportation etc.

Dr Rakesh Arya, Dr RR Sinha, Dr BMK Sinha and Dr Manjushree Singh have also expressed their personal views on Corona virus and shared guidelines of Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India so that the employees and their family did not affect from the Corona virus.

Title: Price monitoring of mask, sanitizer on govt portal
Article:
Chhattisgarh food secretary Dr Kamalpreet Singh on Wednesday directed department officials to upload the price of masks and sanitizers along with 22 other essential commodities on every day on the Centre’s price monitoring portal.

The order comes in the wake of reports of spiraling prices of the products after coronavirus advisories issued by Centre and the state government.

The letter issued to the state controller of food and drugs and other senior department officials, said the Centre’s price monitoring cell has directed the state governments to upload the prices of masks, 2-ply and 3-ply surgical masks, N95 masks, hand sanitizers, alcohol-based floor cleaner, including like, floor disinfectant, liquid soap, hand wash along with the 22other essential commodities being sold in the market, every day that are being sold in the market.

The food secretary in his letter to the district collectors, directed them to monitor the availability of the products through regular monitoring.

The collectors have been asked to hold meetings with traders and business associations in their respective districts and access the availability and review of the stock and price of masks and hand sanitizers, the letter said.

The health and family welfare department has also issued an order authorizing officials to carry out regular inspections and take action against hoarders and black-marketers under the Essential Commodities, Act 1955, of masks and sanitizers.

The Centre on March 13, through a gazette notification, had brought masks, 2-ply and 3-ply surgical masks, N-95 masks, and hand sanitizers as essential commodities under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

Title: Admn to provide compensation for farmers affected by hail, rains
Article:
The farmers whose crops were damaged due to unseasonal rain and hailstorm will be compensated by the district administration under the State Disaster Relief Fund. While issuing a directive to all the Circle officers in this regard, Deputy Commissioner Ranchi Rai Mahimapat Ray said that all officers will set up help desks at their offices for receiving applications from farmers and submit requisition as soon as possible.

Significantly, last week, due to torrential rains and hailstorms in other areas of the state including Ranchi, a large amount of farmers' crops were destroyed. Taking cognizance of this, the Ranchi district administration issued necessary orders in this regard to the circle officers and took an initiative to provide relief to the farmers.

Vegetable crops were damaged due to the heavy rain. The farmers of Ranchi, Ormanjhi, Silli, Itki, Piskangadi and Bero have been affected by the heavy rain fall in the month of March. There is large number of small and marginal farmers who generally grow vegetables in Rabi season instead of wheat.

Many farmers were cultivating vegetable by taking loans from banks. Now, the future of their crops hangs in balance, they said. Vegetables are rotting in the fields. Farmers are saying that they are not getting right price of their products either.

The crops of Peas, Tomatoes, French Beans, Cauliflower and others have been affected in Bero Block area. Due to rain from Friday night to Saturday evening, standing crops have suffered a lot. A group of farmers including Bindeshwar Mahato, Umesh Mahato, Devendra Mahato, Durga Mahato said that water has accumulated in the fields due to continuous rains which is damaging vegetable crops.

In Silli Block also vegetable crops in 200 acres were spoiled due to hailstorm in many places. Crops like French Beans, Tomatoes, Cabbage, Cauliflower and other vegetables got damaged. A farmer Bhriguram Koiri, resident of Nayak Jobla, said that Nayak Jobla and Jobla villages are the major vegetable producing areas under Silli Block. “Due to rain and bad weather, the crop on almost 200 acres of land in these two villages was ruined. On Saturday, tomatoes sold at Rs.5 per KG. Price is expected to rise in a week,” he added.

Qayum Ansari, a resident of Khakhara under Budhamu Block had cultivated Potatoes and Peas by taking a loan of Rs 90 thousand from a Nationalized Bank. “Due to crop failure it will be difficult to repay the loan. Potato crop has been destroyed due to flooding of fields,” he added.

Title: Travellers returning from Dubai hide travel history; placed in home isolation
Article:
A Congress leader from Chhattisgarh who along with 32 others had returned from Dubai and landed at the Swami Vivekananda Airport Raipur did not voluntarily disclose their travel history, an official said on Wednesday.

The group has been kept in home isolation, the officials said.

Ramesh Varliyani along with 70 others had gone to Dubai on March 8 and had landed at the Raipur airport on March 14 along with 32 others.

However, once they landed at Raipur, they did not disclose their foreign travel history at the volunteer disclosure counter at the airport, an airport official said.

It was through the tour operator that their travel history came to light, following which they were tracked down, the official said.

Later, when the matter came to light, chief minister Bhupesh Baghel expressed dismay over the incident, following which they were kept in home isolation.

Meanwhile, health department officials said that the group is being constantly monitored and after the quarantine period of 14 days is over and if they do not show symptoms of coronavirus (COVID 19), they will be released.

Title: CS allows Govt staff to work from home
Article:
The chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh has issued orders for all government offices to curtail the number of employees visiting the office as a precautionary measure to check the spread of novel coronavirus.

Singh has directed all the additional chief secretaries, principal secretaries, secretarites, heads of departments and office that from March 19 to 25 only those personnel should be called to the office whose presence in office is vital in interest of work. The remaining employees should be permitted to work from home. These directions will not apply to those employed in essential services including health department, police, transport, food supply, electricity, potable water and sanitation among others. While directing that employees be allowed to work from home, Singh directed that they should be available on phone and when called to the office, will discharge the given official work.

He further said that district magistrates will be authorised to take the services of any departmental employee for preventing spread of COVID-19 or other official necessity.Further, considering earlier order issued by additional chief secretary Radha Raturi, the secretariat will remain open for important works and works will be executed as per orders issued by chief secretary.

Title: Remaining part of Budget session at Dehradun: CM
Article:
The second part of the budget session of Uttarakhand assembly would now be held in Dehradun. Making this declaration here on Wednesday, the Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said that remaining part of Budget session would now be held at Dehradun. The first part of the budget session was held at Gairsain. The threat posed due to the spread of Coronavirus is being viewed as the reason of shifting of venue of remaining part of the budget session. It is learnt that the state government consulted Congress leaders Indira Hridayesh and Pritam Singh before changing the venue of second part of the budget session.The budget session of Uttarakhand assembly started at Bhararidain near Gairsain in Chamoli district on March 3. The session was adjourned on March 7 (Saturday) by the speaker Premchand Agarwal till March 25. The remaining part of the session is expected to be of three days.

The Chief Minister Trivendra Singh Rawat had presented who also holds the finance portfolio had presented a budget of Rs 53526.97 Crore for the financial year 2020-21 at Gairsain. In the second part of the session, the departmental budgets would be passed by the assembly in Dehradun.

Title: State machinery gears up to stall COVID-19 spread
Article:
Necessary precautionary measures and a work-plan to tackle any possible situation in view of the spread of novel coronavirus should be ensured across the state.

The chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh issued this direction while chairing a video conference with various departmental heads, district magistrates, senior superintendents of police, chief medical officers, district supply officers and other officers concerned.

He directed that the distribution and supply of essential public services should be maintained without break and in a protective manner. There should be no gaps in such essential services. Food supply, fuel supply and medical services should be maintained in a systematic manner. Singh directed all the district magistrates and officials concerned to make better plans and observe the same for this purpose.

Proper sanitisation and social distance should be maintained in all departmental work places while awareness on the do’s and donts’ should also be raised among the employees.

Singh directed the supply department to ensure that adequate transport and supply chain is maintained from the gowdown to the outlet to ensure secured supply of food grains, petrol and cooking gas among other essential supplies. Token system and minimum distance should be observed at fair price shops and other such places which tend to be crowded. He directed the district magistrates to closely monitor the situation to ensure the facilitation while also coordinating with Vyapar Mandal and transport associations in matters related to food grain supply and such essential items.

The chief secretary also directed the chief medical officers to ensure that medical services are provided as per the guidelines issued by the government, stressing that there should be no negligence in providing medical care to any suspect case.

Singh further directed that exercise be conducted regarding protection from coronavirus. Coordination should be established in advance with industrial organisations ready to help in necessary equipment- construction material needed in case there is any type of critical situation.

He directed all heads of government offices to enable personnel to work from home, adding that if required they can be called to the office on the phone.

Title: Health minister appeals to people to remain alert, safe
Article:
State health and family welfare minister TS Singhdeo on Wednesday appealed to people to remain alert and safe from the coronavirus infection.

In a message to the people of the state, Singhdeo said there is need to fight the coronavirus just by remaining alert and adopting preventive measures, as once it spreads, then everyone will have to face a large-scale danger.

To curb the spread the Covit-19 outbreak, everyone should cooperate with the doctors, nurses and the health department officials and healthcare staff.

Thanking private sector doctors and nurses for their dedicated service, the minister said that people have to fight the disease together.

“It is a tough time that each and every one of us is passing through due to the coronavirus scare. Therefore, one has to remain in total alert mode and must be understanding to face the situation,” he said.

The health department has constituted a rapid response team since January 27 and it is fortunate that until now there not a single coronavirus case has been detected in the state, Singhdeo said, adding that 450 people suspected with the symptoms of Covit-19 are being treated in the state while 1,500 people are being kept in isolation for which arrangements have been put into place.

A new 60-bede hospital has been readied to treat people with the disease and further capacity is being enhanced, he said.

Singhdeo urged the people to cooperate with screening of coronavirus and identification of suspected cases.

Title: Japanese anti-flu medicine effective in COVID-19
Article:
Medical experts in China have claimed that a new flu drug is 'clearly effective' in treating the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.

Favipiravir, the active ingredient in a Japanese anti-flu medicine called Avigan, was trialled on 340 patients with the disease in China, reported dailymail.co.uk

Patients who took the flu drug recovered quicker and showed greater lung improvement compared with patients not given the drug.

The component is thought to block the virus from replicating in the body.

Doses will be investigated in more COVID-19 patients by Hong Kong researchers, who claim they will give their pill 'for free' if studies show it is safe.

However, contradictory clinical trials suggest Favipiravir will not be useful in patients who have more severe illness.

As of yet, there isn't a treatment for the coronavirus pandemic. Most people have mild symptoms and can recover at home within a week.

Almost 200,000 have been infected and 7,900 have died.

It was given to 80 patients in Shenzen and in Wuhan, where the novel coronavirus first emerged in December 2019.

Favipiravir has been effective, with no obvious side-effects, in helping coronavirus patients recover, Zhang Xinmin, an official at China's Science and Technology Ministry, told reporters at a news conference on Tuesday.

An oral medicine using favipiravir, developed by Hong Kong-based Sihuan Pharmaceutical, is also in line to try on COVID-19 patients.

Led by Beijing Chaoyang Hospital, a clinical trial is part of a programme by Sihuan and the Institute of Microbiology Epidemiology, a division of the Chinese armed forces.

The study will involve 60 COVID-19 patients who will be given treatment for around 10 days. Larger trials are expected later.

Sihuan executive director Che Fengsheng has said, "After all the efforts and preparations, our group is fully prepared for favipiravir's raw material and preparation production."

Title: Locked at home, NRIs from State face tough times amid restrictions
Article:
Non-Resident Indians (NRIs) hailing from Jharkhand are facing a tough time in foreign nations as the fear of Coronavirus has led to lockdowns and even curfews in some parts of the world. While fetching Indian grocery has become a daunting task in foreign shores, some NRI’s plans of visiting home – either to attend events or address exigencies – had to be cancelled as the fear of being quarantined has gripped foreign travelers to India.

Nishant Priya, a software engineer based out of New Jersey in the United States of America (USA) said that there was no supply of Indian grocery to his city, and other daily-use products too were not easily available. The administration there has clamped curfew from 8pm to 5am in New Jersey, and people have been locked in their own houses. “I have an infant at home, and even diapers are not available in the market. We have been forced to stay indoors and move out only when the curfew is lifted,” said Priya, originally a resident of Ranchi.

The situation may not be as severe in Dubai as in New Jersey, but Indians living in UAE are avoiding visits to India fearing quarantine. TS Nand, a Geo-Scientist based out of Dubai, could not come to India to attend his brother’s open-heart surgery due to the various restriction imposed on travelers. “I had to be in India to support my family at a time when my brother is undergoing an open-heart surgery but I could not come. I will be quarantined if I come to India, and I cannot afford that at this moment,” he said.

Coronavirus has killed more than 100 people in the USA and infected around113 in the UAE. More than 2 lakh people have been infected by the lethal virus across the globe and over 8,000 of them have died. While India is taking all possible measures to prevent the virus from spreading, and screening foreign travelers is an important part of the drill, the preventive measures have hit some NRIs hard.

However, Indians stuck in Japan, where more than 600 people have been infected by the virus, have not been restricted to their homes. Shashwat Satyawrat, an engineer working in Japan, said that educational institutions have been shut in his city till April, but shops are open. “The cases of Coronavirus surged in Japan in February, but they are now under control. We are also going to office daily, and there is no major restriction as such,” he said.

Prafull Nanda, a native of Simdega living in Ghana Republic, said that the country is still in stage one of Coronavirus and serious restrictions have not been imposed. However, some locals in Ghana fear that outsiders, including Indians, may bring Coronavirus to the country and infect them, he said. “I have had a few such encounters recently. Most of times, they (locals) stare at me as if I am carrying Coronavirus with me. Sometimes, they joking ask me not to spread the virus,” said Nanda as he chuckled. “It is not serious discrimination, but it is funny,” he added.

Title: Police and revenue dept officials deployed at Raipur airport
Article:
Stepping up the coronavirus (COVID-19) screening drive at the Swami Vivekananda airport Raipur, the state government on Wednesday deployed additional police personnel and revenue department officials at the airport.

The step come after the health department complained that travellers were not cooperating with screening and quarantine protocol in place at the airport, official here said.

A Congress leader of Chhattisgarh along with 32 fellow travellers had returned from a trip to Dubai few days back. They, however, did not disclose their travel history at Raipur airport and went on their regular routine lives.

Later, when the matter came to light, chief minister Bhupesh Baghel expressed his utter dismay e over the incident, following which the group was kept in home isolation.

The officials said due to non-cooperation from travelers, the functioning of the quarantine centre at Jhanjh in Nava Raipur and Nimora was hampered.

Taking the circumstances into account, the health department has requested the state home department to deploy extra police personnel at these places.

Meanwhile, chief minister Bhupesh Baghel and health minister TS Singhdeo requested people to voluntarily disclose history of their foreign travel on the helpline number 104 so that the spread of the coronavirus could be stopped.

Title: Civil court Daltonganj opens medical checkup kiosk
Article: A medical checkup kiosk has been set up in the civil court of Palamu at Daltonganj. The kiosk was jointly inaugurated by the principal judge, Family Court Bansidhar Tiwari, acting district & sessions judge Pankaj Kumar 2, civil surgeon John F Kennedy in presence of a battery of judges like M Ranjan, Asif Eqbal, Amresh Kumar, Anand Prakash, Nirupam Kumar, Safdar Ali Naiyyar and others. Speaking to media persons Pankaj Kumar 2 said this medical checkup kiosk will function every Wednesday from 1.30 PM onwards.

Title: CM asks people not to panic, remain careful
Article:
Chief Minister Hemant Soren has directed all the Deputy Commissioners and officers of the district to ensure strict compliance of the directive issued related to coronavirus. The CM said, “We all have a responsibility to avoid rumors related to Corona virus. Share the correct information, ignoring the rumours. We can prevent this infection through social support. No need to panic with coronavirus. We always have to be alert.”

Meanwhile, the CM was informed that Daniyal Barjo, resident of Kichinda village in Gudri block died due to lack of ambulance /Mamta Vahan on time. Seeing the seriousness of the matter, the CM ordered Deputy Commissioner Chaibasa to investigate the matter and take strict action and inform about it.

The CM expressed discontent over the matter and asked where and why lapses are occurring. “To my knowledge, there is also availability of sufficient Mamta Vahans in the State. All the Deputy Commissioners should review the Mamta Vahan with 108 ambulances and formulate a strategy to provide service to the people, so that such cases can be stopped completely,” he said.

Title: Assembly panel to probe Raipur-based firm work
Article:
The State Government on Wednesday announced to set up an Assembly committee to probe the work carried out by Raipur-based company Agrawal Global Infratech Private Limited Company in State. The company is alleged to have links with an ‘influential person’ in Jharkhand politics.

On this issue the budget session of Jharkhand Assembly on Wednesday witnessed uproar with opposition BJP and ruling party legislators slamming each other over on the question raised by independent MLA Saryu Roy over the road widening tender provided to company.

Roy raising the query in question hour said that road widening work of Hunterganj-Pandepur-Pratappur road was given to Agrawal Global Infratech Private Limited Company in March 2017 at a cost of Rs 7933.149 lakh. But, at the same time in January 13, 2017, as per documents of Indian Company Registration Act, the company was registered as having no work experience.

Roy, who contested and defeated former chief minister Raghubar Das from Jamshedpur East in last Assembly election, alleged that the company is related to very influential person of State and the company has been working not only in the road construction department, but also in many other departments.

The Jamshedpur East MLA alleged that the company is from Chhattisgarh and also has a hotel named Clarke in Raipur. Roy said, “The son of that influential person was also married at the same hotel. Therefore, the matter should be investigated by Anti Corruption Bureau (ACB).”

Replying to Roy’s allegation, in-charge minister Badal said that Hemant Soren government will not do anything with bad intention and the matter is in the High Court. He said that the work was given to the company on the advice of former advocate general Ajit Kumar and the investigation cannot be carried out as the matter is subjudice.

Intervening Badal, Roy said that on earlier occasions he had raised the issue of former advocate general Ajit Kumar in the House as former advocate general’s advices has been marred with controversies and in such situation how can the advice of then advocate general can be taken so seriously.

Roy was supported by fellow MLAs Pradeep Yadav, Bandhu Tirkey and Rajendra Singh on this matter who demanded that the matter concern with an influential person so it should investigated.

Bandhu Tirkey intervening said that being the case sub judice doesn’t restrict in carrying out investigation in the case. Tirkey citing his reference (example) said that a case a pending against him, but the Raghubar Das government at that time made an inquiry against me by constituting SIT.

The two MLAs Bandhu Tirkey and Yadav said without delay the government should order a probe in the case saying that the influential person associated with the case is none other than former Chief Minister Raghubar Das. At the same time, as the pressure on the investigation of the matter increased in the House, the BJP MLAs protested after being given time for so long on a question and came to the well creating ruckus.

Title: Coronavirus: Punjab mulling to release 5,800 jail inmates
Article:
Lodged in jails for petty and minor offences, no less than 5,800 inmates may find themselves out of prison with the Punjab Government considering the decongestion of “overcrowded” jails in the wake of coronavirus threat.

For the same, the State Government is taking up the matter with the Chief Justice of the Punjab and Haryana High Court as it was up to the courts to have final say in the matter.

As of now, Punjab has a total of 23,800 prisoners lodged in its 19 jails, including nine central prisons, against a housing capacity for only 23,300 inmates.

“The State Government is mulling giving bail to those convicted for minor offences and parole to those who have spent considerable time in jail,” said Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh pointing out that the Supreme Court had also talked about decongesting the prisons.

“The final decision would, however, depend on the courts and the state Advocate-General Atul Nanda is taking up the matter with the Chief Justice of the Punjab and Haryana High Court,” he added.

The State Jails Minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhwa has sent a proposal for the release of 5,800 inmates, of which 2,800 were held for petty crimes, and other 3,000 criminals were caught with small quantity drugs.

“There are concerns that the crime rates may go up after the release of these prisoners. However, the state DGP and ADGP have discussed the issue with SPs and a decision will be taken accordingly,” said Randhawa adding that these measures have been suggested to prevent the spread of coronavirus outbreak in jails.

Randhawa said he made these suggestions to the Chief Minister in a meeting which was called after the Supreme Court took cognisance of the country's overcrowded prisons being a fertile ground for the spurt in coronavirus cases and suggesting remedial measures.

Taking suo motu cognisance of overcrowding in jails, the Apex Court bench of Chief Justice SA Bobde and Justice LN Rao had, on Monday, issued notices to prisons’ director generals and chief secretaries of all states and Union Territories, seeking to know by March 20 the steps taken to prevent corona outbreak in jails.

At the same time, the Minister said that the authorities were also sanitising the jails as a preventive measure against coronavirus.

Title: Shreemandir Yes Bank fund to be withdrawn today
Article:
The total funds amounting to Rs 545 crore of the Jagannath Temple here parked in the crisis-hit Yes Bank would be withdrawn on Thursday as the moratorium imposed on the bank is set to be lifted at 6 pm on Wednesday.

The withdrawn money would be transferred to the UCO Bank, Main Branch, Puri in two transactions through e-transfer on Thursday, said Shree Jagannath Temple Administration (SJTA) Development Officer Ajay Kumar Jena to mediapersons here.

“While Rs 389 crore deposited in the Yes Bank on March 19, 2019 is maturing tomorrow, rest Rs 156 crore will mature on March 30. The SJTA has decided to withdraw the entire Rs 545 crore from the bank tomorrow. Intimation for withdrawal of Rs 389 crore was given to the Yes Bank yesterday and further intimation will be submitted today for the rest amount,” Jena asserted.

The SJTA had earlier written to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) for transfer of Rs 545 crore to the UCO Bank. The money was deposited in the Yes Bank by the temple administration in shape of TDRs.

Recently, State Finance Minister Niranjan Pujari had stated that the funds were deposited in the Yes Bank as it offered the highest rate of interest of 8.61%. The SJTA had invited quotations from scheduled commercial banks for depositing the money while 12 banks gave proposals in this regard.

Title: 2,131 foreign returnees registered so far
Article:
A total of 2,131 persons who returned from 80 countries have registered themselves on the State Government’s COVID-19 portal so far.

State Government’s Chief Spokesperson on COVID-19 Subroto Bagchi told a Press conference here on Wednesday that out of these foreign returnees, as many as 20% are from the United Arab Emirate (UAE), 9% from the US, 4% from the UK and 1% each from Italy, Korea and France.

Notably, no resident of Odisha has returned from China, the country from where the COVID-19 pandemic first broke out.

Of the total 2,131 registered persons, 37% are residents of Khordha district followed by those of Cuttack, Ganjam, Kendrapada and Baleswar. Out of the State’s 30 districts, suspected coronavirus cases have been reported from 29 districts, the exception being Malkangiri.

Bagchi said swab samples of 47 persons of the State with suspected symptoms of coronavirus had been sent for tests. Of them, 46 were found to be negative while one person tested positive and has been kept under observation at the Capital Hospital in Bhubaneswar and is now taking normal diet.

Bagchi further informed that 540 isolation beds have been kept ready at district hospitals and medical colleges and more such beds would be added in coming days.

In the past 24 hours, 104 helpline numbers received calls from 5,202 persons, he also informed.

Title: ‘Corona quarantine same as Jagannath’s Anasara’
Article:
State Government COVID-19 Chief Spokesperson Subroto Bagchi on Wednesday likened corona-related quarantine to Lord Jagannath’s Anasara.

“Lord Jagannath has quarantine every year, once after He comes into contact with too many of His worshipers. He actually contracts cold which is a virus-led thing. He is quarantined for exactly 14 days, same 14 days as in chickenpox and coronavirus. He is given the right kind of medication, the right kind of food and then He bounces back,” Bagchi quipped.

Bagchi drew the analogy during a news conference here.

Notably, during the Snana Purnima, bathing ritual of the sibling deities, ahead of the annual Rath Yatra, 108 pitchers of aromatic and herb-mixed water is poured on Lords Jagannath and Balabhadra and Devi Subhadra.

After the ritual, the deities fall sick and keep away from public view. They are given special medicines and take 14 days to recover from the illness. This period is known as Anasara and the place where they get nursed is called Anasara Ghara.

Title: Jadibuti smoke blown to prevent corona
Article:
To prevent novel coronavirus (COVID-19) from spreading, the Santhashree Asharamji Ashram at Dhauli has started a programme of blowing Jadibuti Dhuan (herbal smoke).

A ‘Dhuan Rath’ (smoke chariot) has been moving and releasing herbal smokes in different parts of the State capital city for the last four days. It started rolling from the Old Town area. Various kinds of herbs are being mingled and fired with Mahagugul, dried cow dung, neem leafs, bel leafs, ghee, karpur for creation of smoke. Ashram members claim that the coronavirus would not enter the area where the smoke is released. Shailendra Narayan Senapati, Surjyamani Samal and Akshay Rout are participating in the programme, among others.

Title: City wears deserted look, people remain indoor
Article:
The city is wearing a deserted look these days with Corona scare gripping people. Though no positive case has been found but still the city is under preventive mode. MGM Medical College has sent four foreign students back home. According to information, students from 2016 batch Farzana Islam from Bangladesh and Sugandha Rani Gupta from Nepal, while students from 2017 batch Puja Yadav and Snigdha who also came from aboard have also left the campus.

“Though there has been no positive case in our city but as per orders from the administration we have vacated our hostels and foreign students have been asked to go back home,” said an official of MGM Medical College.

Deputy Commissioner East Singhbhum, Ravi Shankar Shukla who took stock of the preparedness to combat the spread of pandemic Corona virus said the situation is much under control and there is nothing to panic.

“We request people to cooperate with administration and take preventive measures,” said Shukla. The DC said that all protective and curative measures were being put in place as per central and state governments’ directives in the matter.

Meanwhile, three teams on Wednesday started scanning visitor registers at hotel, lodges, clubs and guesthouses.

“ We have intensified our inspection. Separate teams have been constituted for areas under Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee (JNAC), Mango Notified Area Committee (MNAC) and Jugsalai municipality.

Each of the team led by special officers of the respective civic body are scanning registers and seeking details on a daily basis of visitors at each of the hotels, clubs, guest houses and lodges and submitting report at my office,” said East Singhbhum additional district magistrate (law and order), Nand Kishore Lal.

City manager Ravi Shankar Bharti conducted inspection at such hotels, clubs and lodges in Jamshedpur area and submitted report to JNAC special officer Krishna Kumar, similar drive was conducted in Mango by city manager MNAC, Nishant Kumar and report submitted to Deepak Sakay, special officer MNAC.

Hotels and guesthouses along Tatanagar Station Road and Jugsalai were inspected by city manager, Jugsalai, Rajendra Kumar and report submitted to Jagdish Prasad Yadav, special officer Jugsalai municipality.

Meanwhile, district administration has also activated inter-district and inter-state check-points at 12 locations.

The check-points have been activated from Wednesday at Jagannathpur and Kaliadia (both in Baharagora), Chakulia (for visitors coming from Odisha and Bengal), Ghurabandha (bordering Odisha), Bodam and Patamda (Bengal), Potka and Hata (Odisha), Pardih (from NH-33), New Domuhani Bridge (NH-33), Adityapur Toll Bridge and Ghatshila.

Title: EOW registers FIR to probe role of officers in PDS scam
Article:
The state economic offences wing (EOW) registered a case in the alleged multi-crore Public Distribution System (PDS) scam, which took place during the previous BJP government's tenure, and launched a probe into the role of concerned officials.

The case was registered on Tuesday after a probe revealed the irregularities committed by the officials who were employed with the food department and incurred a loss of Rs 2,718 crore to the exchequer, a press release from here said.

As per the 2011 socio-economic census, there were 56,50,724 families in the state and there should have been 45 lakh ration cards, it said.

But by the end of 2013, a total of 71,30,393 ration cards existed across the 27 districts of Chhattisgarh, indicating that there were 14.80 lakh bogus ration cards as the number of families in the state was only 56.5 lakh, the release said.

From July 2013 to December 2013, as many as 41,847 ration cards were invalidated. But until 2016, new ration cards were issued every year and some of them were canceled after it came to light that they were bogus, it added.

Between April 2013 and December 2016, 11,08,515 tons of rice was distributed at subsidized rate against these bogus ration cards which were eventually canceled, incurring a loss of Rs 2,718 crore to the state government, it said.

The responsibility of transportation and distribution of food grains lay with the Directorate of Food Department and the transportation agency, it mentioned.

The officials who were then posted with the food department, misused their powers to facilitate issuance of bogus cards and distribution of foodgrain through them, the release said.

The EOW is now probing the scam and the role of civil servants, it added.

Title: Circuit House Sai Mandir shuts down
Article:
The managing committee of Sri Sai Centre at Circuit House, in an emergency meeting has decided to suspend visits of devotees to the temple from Wednesday, March 18 as precautionary measure in view of the COVID – 19 (Coronavirus) pandemic prevailing almost globally.

VK Mehta, president, Sri Sai Centre and Rohan Mehta informed that the step had been taken as a precautionary measure. “We hope the devotees will understand and cooperate,” they said.

However, the usual worship rituals like Baba’s Arti, Abhishek and consecrated food (Bhog) will continue with the temple priests performing these spiritual processes. The Circuit House Sai Temple will remain closed until further notification.

Title: Preventive measures put into place at Nava Raipur
Article:
Preventive measures have been put into place at new capital city, Nava Raipur, Atal Nagar from Wednesday in the wake of the coronavirus alert (COVID-19) advisory issued by the Centre and the state governments.

At the secretariat building (Mahanadi Bhawan) and offices of the departmental heads (Indiravati Bhawan) sanitization protocol will carried out every day.

All the lifts, railings of staircases, common areas and waiting areas are being cleaned regularly and sanitized.

The BRTS buses between Raipur and Nava Raipur, too are being cleaned thoroughly every day to sanitize the vehicles. Officials are regularly inspecting the public transport system in the state capital.

The evening shows of the musical fountain at the ‘Rajdhani Sarovar’ have been shut down until further notice. All bio-metric attendance use has in government offices too have been shut down.

Nava Raipur, Atal Nagar Development Authority general manager (administration) said all the protocols are being followed to implement the state government’s advisory and guidelines on the preventing and controlling the spread of the infectious viral disease.

The authority officials and employees have been directed to remain at the headquarters, the general manager said.

Effective steps have also been taken as part of the preventive measures in all the residential sectors, central park, Ekatma Path and others other clusters in the state capital.

All community events and mass gatherings have been banned until March 31 to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus.

The Nava Raipur-based hospitals and hotels, too have been asked to follow the Union health ministry’s advisory without fail.

All educational institutions have been asked to follow preventive adhere to the regular directives issued by the government.

Chief executive officer, Nava Raipur and Atal Nagar development authority Neelam Namdeo Ekka has urged residents not to fall under the believe rumours and fake news about the Covit-19 virus and remain alert.

Title: SER cancels several trains due to low occupancy
Article:
South Eastern Railway on Wednesday announced cancellation of several trains witnessing low occupancy due to the outbreak of coronavirus .

The Howrah-Mumbai CSMT Duronto Express which travels via Tatanagar railway station will remain cancelled between March 24 and 31 while the Mumbai CSMT-Howrah Duronto Express will remain cancelled between March 25 and April 1.

The list of cancelled trains also includes Tatanagar-Ranchi Express. The train which connects steel city with the capital will remain cancelled from March 20 to March 31. The Rourkela-Barbil Intercity Express will remain cancelled from March 20 to March 31.

While Tatanagar-Chhapra Express and Tatanagar-Chakulia Passenger will also remain cancelled from March 18 and March 19 respectively till March 31 due to various infrastructural and safety related modernization work.

An official of South Eastern Railway ( SER) said following a directive from railway board the decision for cancellation of trains was taken. The sale of tickets has dropped drastically during the past few days and the decision was taken due to low occupancy in those trains. All the railway divisions under our jurisdiction have been informed about the cancellation of trains.

He further informed the Santragachi-MGR Chennai Central Suvidha Special will also remain cancelled between March 20 and March 27 due to low occupancy. The MGR Chennai Central- Santragachi Suvidha Special will remain cancelled between March 21 and March 28.

Another SER train --Puri-Santragachi Special ( Up) and Santragachi -Puri Special ( Dn) will also remain cancelled between March 20 and March 27 Chief reservation supervisor at Tatanagar railway station C. S. Rao said after the spread of corona virus fear Daily for the last couple of days on an average 500 to 600 passengers are cancelling tickets for various destinations including New Delhi, Mumbai , Chennai and other places.

Title: Building more of real resilience to handle crisis
Article:
Organisations have been spending millions on business resilience programs over the last decade or so. The COVID-19 or Corona outbreak has been a good health check of the actual effectiveness of these business resilience programs. The question is, how good is a business resilience program that can’t save enough lives in pandemic situation.

ISO (International Organization for Standardization) has a dedicated compliance standard, ISO 22301:12 that is focused on building business resilience across all key business drivers including, people, process and technology. And in every business resilience initiative people come first. Agree or not? After all a single life is more valuable than any financial or brand specific value a company can build. And looking at it from the other side also, if lives are compromised, both brand and revenue can take a huge hit.

Now coming back to the effectiveness of business resilience programs and their real benefits. With the sudden Corona outbreak, a lot of organisations (many ISO 22301:12 certified) were clueless on how to respond effectively and timely, looking at their neighbours or competitors to act first. And this was in a situation where lives were at stake and every minute mattered when it came to the best decision making.

Some organizations just waited and followed on advisory from their local governments without any proper execution plan in place and many are still figuring out. Many haven’t been able to sufficiently enlighten their employees on the basic precautions to be taken. Worse than that, they have not been able to caution and safeguard their people from false advisory’s, that have created panic amongst millions.

Dig out the policies and stacks of documents/ paperwork and try to find out execution plans around addressing such an outbreak and most organizations would fail to justify. And this can very well be seen on ground with all the chaos around handling the Corona pandemic.

I’m not questioning the compliance programs or organizations like ISO that have built these programs (they are meant to address situations like the one we are in right now), but I’m questioning effective execution. Compliance certificates mean nothing, if some of the most sensitive issues that they are meant to address aren’t getting addressed. So do the certifying bodies need to relook at their audit approach and focus more on the real work done by organizations while certifying them on business resilience standards...

The underlying question that we need to answer is, what needs to be done to make business resilience programs genuinely and effectively address health and safety concerns during a pandemic. In today’s context some of the key ones per me are:

1- Controlling social media to avoid spreading of conflicting and false advisory. For example circulate regulated/ authorised digital content around awareness. This is where governments and social media giants need to step up. And I have seen one of the biggest social media players act on this.

2- Ability to scale up first aid facility and quickly get them to the masses. For example, supplies of essentials to address the pandemic should be optimised and governments should take control of all supplies (to minimise mismanagement and malpractices) of such products and of-course subsidise them (after all every individual has right of sufficient access to basic healthcare facilities in any pandemic situation).

3- Effective use of tech and digital to rollout healthcare and well being programs. Best times to make real use of the high-tech tech and expedite the rollout of products and services that can address mass requirements. Lot of startups are doing amazing stuff that even the multi-billion dollar firms are not able to.

The best analogy to take effective steps is considering it as a war like situation. So work with governments and policy makers to get the best results.

And finally, as a wise person has said, when there is crisis, first calm down.

The views in the write-up are independent and nothing to do with any of writer’s professional associations, including present and past. Abhishek Anand is a Management Consultant, who has been part of multiple industry defining initiatives in both emerging and developed markets, including South Asia, North America, Africa, Middle East and Europe.

Title: 3-fold rise in number of under observation Jharkhandis
Article:
The number of Jharkhand residents under observation amid Coronavirus fear has tripled in the past one week – an indication that while the health machinery is leaving no stone unturned to keep the lethal virus at bay, the number of travelers returning to the State from foreign shores is rapidly increasing, officials from the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) said.

According to figures with the IDSP, around 80 people – all with travel history to foreign countries – were under observation and self quarantined in Jharkhand on March 11. However, the latest figures with the IDSP show that the number of people under observation increased to 233 by Tuesday evening.

“At present, not only the ones traveling from foreign countries, but also the local residents who have stayed in close proximity to the travelers are being kept under surveillance,” said IDSP State Director Rakesh Dayal.

However, amid the panic and pandemonium related to COVID-19 and its impact on the human race, Jharkhand residents may take a sigh of relief as the test results of at least 100 of the 233 people kept under observation here have come out negative. “We can say that more than half of the people kept under observation in Jharkhand have not tested positive for Coronavirus. We are keeping our fingers crossed and trying to do our best in ensuring that no positive case is reported from the State,” Dayal said.

The number of positive cases of Coronavirus rose to 151 in India on Wednesday, and the country is still said to be in the second stage of the pandemic. In case, the pandemic reaches its third stage in India, then it may lead to a complete lockdown across the country, said Dayal. The concerned in Jharkhand have been in touch with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, which has been taking regular updates about the situation in Jharkhand, sources said.

By now, no cases of Coronavirus have been reported in Jharkhand. However, the first case of Kolkata – the nearest metro city – was reported on Tuesday.

Title: Corona: Religious bodies to follow norms
Article:
In view of fast-spreading of the coronavirus, the State Government on Wednesday issued an advisory to all religious institutions asking them to strictly adhere to the coronavirus prevention norms, including social distancing.

The Chief Secretary’s office has issued a letter o all district Collectors and the Endowment Commissioner in this regard.

“Concerned agencies, boards, trusts and governing institutions have been advised to take a conscious decision immediately to protect the pilgrims, priests, sevayats and other security personnel involved,” said an official release.

In case any religious institution is not able to maintain all the precautions for CV, the said institution has been advised to immediately restrict the entry of pilgrims while continuing with the rituals.

Title: Rape conviction rate just 27.2%: Experts
Article:
The 2012 Nirbhaya case is nearing closure with the four men held guilty of the crime scheduled to be hanged on Friday, but the conviction rate for rape remains an abysmal 27.2 per cent due mainly to lapses in the criminal justice system, say experts. From sensitising police personnel to strengthening the investigating infrastructure, what is needed is a complete overhaul of the system to ensure speedy justice to victims and survivors of sexual assault, they said.

"The low conviction rate shows that perpetrators of sexual violence enjoy a high degree of impunity, including being freed of charges," said Vani Subramanian from the women's empowerment group Saheli. Calling for an overhaul of the judicial system, former National Commission for Women (NCW) chief Lalitha Kumaramangalam said, "It took seven years (since 2012) to get justice and there are hundreds of cases which do not evoke this kind of a response (that the Nirbhaya case got). We must have a moratorium on time."

According to the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), 1,56,327 rape cases were on trial in 2018. Of these, trials were completed in 17,313 cases, resulting in conviction in only 4,708 cases. There were acquittals in 11,133 rape cases and discharge in 1,472 cases.

A case can be discharged before charges are framed but acquittals only happen when the trial concludes. Moreover, 1,38,642 rape cases remained pending in 2018.

"The case of the 23-year-old physiotherapy intern who was savagely gangraped on the night of December 16, 2012, and died a fortnight later, galvanising a movement for change in India's rape laws, is not an isolated one.

"Sexual assault occurs with frightening regularity in this country. We need to evolve punishments that act as true deterrents to the very large number of men who commit these crimes," said Subramanian.

Of the six convicted in the Nirbhaya case, one died during trial and another, a juvenile at the time of the offence, was set free after serving a three-year term in a reform facility. The four remaining convicts in the case are scheduled to be hanged together at 5.30 am on March 20. The implementation of their death warrants may send a strong message across but that may not be enough.

The situation could actually be getting worse rather than better. The 2018 conviction rate of 27.2 per cent was significantly less that in 2017 — when a conviction rate of 32.2 per cent was recorded. There were convictions only in 5,822 of the 18,099 rape cases whose trials were completed during that year, the NCRB data showed.

Title: Man who lost money in Yes Bank scripts BMW robbery during pee to stop EMI, held
Article:
Unable to pay his car installments, a stock broker, who concocted a story about the robbery of his BMW car here four days ago, has been arrested along with his brother-in-law and a friend by Noida Police.

The BMW car, which had a loan of over Rs 40 lakh pending on it, has also been recovered, the police said.

Those arrested have been identified as stock broker Mukesh Arora, his brother-in-law Rishab Arora and their friend Sumit Gehlotra, Central Noida's Deputy Commissioner of Police Harish Chander said.

"Mukesh Arora had made investments in Yes Bank, which recently met with a financial crisis, and lost a lot of money. He had purchased this BMW car and had Rs 45 lakh loan pending on it but was finding difficult to pay the EMIs," Chander told reporters. His brother-in-law Rishabh, who lives in Sector 137, had claimed that he had stopped along a road to relieve himself on the night of March 14 when some unidentified miscreants held him at gunpoint and fled with the vehicle, the police said.

The police had filed an FIR under IPC section 392 (robbery) but had suspected an insider's role in the episode.

Title: Lawyers can apply for CM Advocates Welfare Scheme from March 21
Article:
The Delhi Government has set up a timeline and a customised on-line application with OTP facility for the welfare of the advocates. The advocates practising in various Delhi courts are eligible to avail the benefits under 'Chief Minister's Advocates Welfare Scheme'.

This may be recalled on December 18, 2019, Delhi Cabinet had passed the recommendations made by the Rakesh Kahnna committee comprising group (team) insurance for parctising advocates life cover of Rs 10 lakh per advocates, Group Medi-claim coverage for advocates and their spouse and two dependent children up the age of 25 years , E- library with 10 computers loaded with e-journals with web edition and creche facility

According to Delhi Ggovernment's notification, now advocates can fill the application forms who intend to avail the benefits of the scheme.

According to Law Minister Kailsah Gehlot, the link on the website of the law department shall get activated on March 21 at 9:30 am which will remain active till March 31."In recognition of the role being played by the Advocates in the society and the legal profession, in particular, this scheme is being introduced by our Government," Gehlot said.

As per the recommendation of Rakesh Khanna committee, Group (Term) Insurance for practising advocates providing life cover of Rs 10 lakhs per advocate. Group Medi-claim coverage for the advocates, their spouse and two dependent children up to the age of 25 years, for a family floater sum insured of Rs 5 lakhs. E-library with 10 computers loaded with e-journals and web editions of e-journals, along with printers in all the 6 district courts and Creche facility for advocates and staff employees in each of the 6 district courts were few benefits under the scheme.

According to Delhi government, there are six district courts in Delhi. The committee recommended setting up of e-libraries in all. Advocates who are now practising in the District Courts will not face any problem in conducting legal research. Now e-library will be set up in all 10 Courts, Tis Hazari Court, Patiala House Court, Karkardooma Court, Saket Court, Dwarka Court and Rohini Court along with 10 computers and other facilities including e-journal, web editions.

The lawyers will able to access e-journals like Delhi Law Times and the libraries will also have heavy-duty printers and there will be Creche facility for advocates and employees

"In view of the problems faced by women advocates and women employees working in the courts of Delhi, the committee recommended running of crèches in all the six district courts for free. After the notification is issued, crèches can now be set up in all the courts," Delhi government said in its order.

Title: Malls, restaurants see 50% decline in footfall amid virus fear
Article:
Deserted restaurants, empty showrooms and closed multiplexes, malls in the national Capital amid coronavirus outbreak are a pale shadow of their former bustling selves.

Be it South Delhi's posh Select City Walk mall, its neighbour and newly-renovated DLF Avenue Mall or West Delhi's favourite go-to destination Pacific Mall, all have been at the receiving end of the coronavirus pandemic, witnessing over "50 per cent" decline in the footfalls so far.

"The fear of the novel coronavirus outbreak has resulted into 60 per cent less footfall in the mall. Shutting down of theatres is also the reason behind the sharp decline I guess," said Ankit Seth, Manager, Bath & Body Works at Select City mall.

The Delhi government on March 12 declared the coronavirus (COVID-19) an epidemic and decided to shut down cinema halls, schools and colleges till March 31 in the national capital as a precautionary measure. Decision on the closure of malls is still awaited.

Even weekends did little to bring back the absent cheer in the various plush stores which visibly remained empty during the good part of the day and staff members outnumbered customers by a fair margin.

"I have been working as a salesman for over 13 years now but I have never seen this slow business in a mall, and that too on weekends," said a salesperson of a famous clothing brand on the condition of anonymity.

"To be honest, it is as good as being shut. Forget about getting good sale numbers, people are just not visiting the mall in the first place," he said.

Home Centre, a well-known home furnishing retail stores chain, refused to comment on the sales or dip in footfalls in their store. While the coffee shops, food court or sit-in are still registering a decent customer count, the situation is stark opposite for several fancy stand-alone and fine dining restaurants with staff members idly standing by empty tables.

"Yes, the dip in footfall is for everyone to see. There is hardly any customer in most of the restaurants. There are no cancellations, because people are hardly making any bookings," said an employee of Mamagoto in Select City mall.

Things were no different for Hotel Delmaar, Saatvik, Punjab Grill or the recently-opened Daryaganj restaurant in Pacific mall -- all waiting desperately for customers but to no avail.

Interesting enough, the few who did turn up in the mall amidst this widespread fear of the deadly virus said this would be their "last visit" till the time the dust settles on the highly contagious disease.

"I mainly came because of my children. They were so hell-bent that they had to go and were not ready to take no for anything. But then I have made things very clear that this one would be for the last time until things improve. Also, we don't plan to stay for long," said 35-year-old Gurpreet Singh, who had come to Pacific mall along with his family members.

That said, most of these malls are claiming to follow all the guidelines issued in the health advisory by the government to ensure "hygiene and clean environment" in the premises.

Besides providing sanitizers at entrance, washrooms and lobbies, Select City mall also has the facility of thermal scanners checking the temperature of incoming visitors at different entry points.

"The housekeeping staff has been guided to wipe door handles, escalator belts, lift handrails, lift buttons, WC seat covers and faucets at increased frequency and hourly mopping with Virex II 256 disinfectant.

"Also, a communication has been sent to the retailers in the shopping centre to keep hand sanitisers at the store entrance so that people entering the store sanitize their hands," said Yogeshwar Sharma, executive director & CEO, Select Infrastructure Pvt. Ltd.

The number of the novel coronavirus cases in India rose to 151 on Wednesday after 14 more were reported from various parts of the country, according to the Health Ministry.

Title: Religious sites sanitised
Article:
In the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, civic bodies in the national Capital have started sanitising major temples, churches and gurudwaras besides setting up temporary mobile wash basin and disinfecting all public places, private offices, including its zonal offices and shopping malls every day.

South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) has screened 10,000 patients at its dispensaries for coronavirus infection. The Public Health Department of SDMC has also deputed eight teams of doctors and nurses at quarantine centers identified by the Delhi Government for performing round the clock duties.

The civic body has also deployed 1,000 nurses for contact surveillance of coronavirus patients. Provision of special queues for patients suffering from fever and cough have also made functional at OPD registrations counters and pharmacies, a senior SDMC official said, adding that the health department has conducted 2,000 meetings with hotel staff, RWAs and market associations for creating mass awareness.

The official said autorikshaws mounted with public announcing system in each zone are engaged. In addition to it, awareness messages are also being displayed on unipoles, toilet blocks and panels inside metro trains.

SDMC Commissioner Gyanesh Bharti has directed officials of the public health department to organise mass awareness campaign in association with RWA and market associations to sensitise the residents about the deadly coronavirus. The SDMC is raising awareness on the coronavirus among people by putting up posters on dos and don'ts regarding the disease at its hospitals, dispensaries, public places, markets, metro, Bharti said.

The North Delhi Municipal Corporation (NMC) Mayor Avtar Singh said temporary mobile wash basin will be set up at public places and around temples and markets.

The NMC has also set up a 50 bedded isolation ward to treat the patients besides issuing an order to owners of hotels, guest houses, malls, restaurants and other recreational establishments to ensure that proper sanitisation facility is available at entry points of their premises. The order also said that these establishments should ensure no crowding or gathering at one particular site.

"All the hotel, motel, guest houses will ensure that proper sanitisation facility (washing with soap and water/alcohol-based sanitiser) is available at the entry point of their respective establishments. Further, they will also ensure that there is no crowding or gathering at one particular site in the premises," it said.

The same directions have been sent to owners of malls, banquet halls, eateries, and to market trader associations and RWAs. East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC) has also cancelled more than 300 bookings of community centres, banquet halls etc for holding marriage and other related ceremony. It has distributed 16,000 masks, 7,000 gloves among the sanitation workers working in different wards, a senior EDMC official said, adding that 390 foreign nationals from China, Thailand, Japan and Singapore stayed in East Corporation area since February, most of them have gone back and those who came in contact with them are being monitored.

Title: Kejriwal, L-G hold meet to contain virus
Article:
With coronavirus cases on rise in the national Capital and its adjoining areas, on Wenesday a high-level meeting between the Lieutenant Governor Anil Baijal and Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal deliberated at length about various steps to contain the spread of Covid -19. Baijal and Kejriwal and other senior officials will meet again on Thursday to review the status and take further steps to tackle the emerging coronavirus situation.

"Discussed measures to contain Covid-19 outbreak with Hon'ble CM, Delhi Arvind Kejriwal. Deliberated social distancing measures which can be encouraged in government offices, public transport, public places & in general," Baijal tweeted. In another tweeted, he said,"Meeting with Hon'ble CM and senior officers to be held tomorrow to review the status and take further measures."

The total number of coronavirus cases in Delhi has risen to 10, which includes one foreign national, the health ministry said on Wednesday. The country has so far reported 151 cases of coronavirus.

Title: Close Govt offices for week, employee body urges CM
Article:
As cases of coronavirus are multiplying in India, a Delhi Government employee association on Wednesday met Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal and demanded closure of all Government offices for a week in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

Notably, around 2.5 lakh people are employed with the Delhi Government and these employees deal with public in day-to-day functioning.

Umesh Batra, general secretary of the Delhi Government Welfare Association in its memorandum, said, "The precaution taken by the Maharashtra Government should be adopted by the Delhi Government by closing all its offices for seven days."

He said the association has requested the Chief Minister that if the Government is not interested in closing all offices, it can allow some public offices to function on alternative days."We have given a list of 86 departments which can be fully closed while 68 Government offices can be allowed to function on alternate days," he said.

"Registrar and MLO offices can be closed because property registration and driving license can be issued later," he said.

The memorandum stated that Delhi Police, responsible for the security of the secretariat, should be given strict instructions to use metal detectors to check people entering the premises. The number of coronavirus cases across the country has risen to 147.

The Delhi Government has declared coronavirus an epidemic and shut down all cinema halls, schools and colleges, except those where exams are on, till March 31. The Government also made it compulsory to disinfect all public places, including Government and private offices and shopping malls, every day.

In its memorandum, the association said, "The precaution taken by the Maharashtra Government should be adopted by the Delhi Government by closing all its offices for seven days."

Batra said the association has requested the Chief Minister that if the Government is not interested in closing all offices, it can allow some public offices to function on alternative days.

"We have given a list of 86 departments which can be fully closed while 68 Government offices can be allowed to function on alternate days," he said.

"Registrar and MLO offices can be closed because property registration and driving license can be issued later," he said.

The memorandum stated that Delhi Police, responsible for the security of the secretariat, should be given strict instructions to use metal detectors to check people entering the premises. The number of coronavirus cases across the country has risen to 147.The Delhi Government has declared coronavirus an epidemic and shut down all cinema halls, schools and colleges, except those where exams are on, till March 31.

Title: ‘District Collectors should take steps to stem Novel Corona’
Article:
Chief Secretary M Gopal Reddy has said that all the District Collectors should take measures and make innovations to prevent Novel Corona virus infection according to the local situation and environment. He said that this challenge can be faced by being self-aware, conducting awareness campaign on a large scale and by constantly monitoring it.

Reddy said that people should be motivated to adopt rescue measures at field level. Effective efforts must be made to limit crowd in social and religious events with the mutual consent of the common people. Chief Secretary Reddy was reviewing the ongoing activities in the state through video conference in Mantralaya to prevent the spread of Novel Corona virus.

Principal Secretary Public Health and Family Welfare Smt. Pallavi Jain Govil informed that passengers coming from the countries affected by Novel Corona virus are being continuously screened in the state. “State Portal for Covid-19 Monitoring” has been developed for information regarding preventive measures against infection and updated status. The support of private hospitals is also being sought.

She said that it is necessary to advise the general public to encourage eating and consuming medicines that boost immunity. The Principal Secretary said that common people can be made partners in efforts to prevent the spread of infection only through the use of information, education and communication. During the video conference, Collectors of Indore, Panna, Seoni, Balaghat, Gwalior, Sagar, Ratlam, Raisen districts gave information about the activities being done at the local level.

Principal Secretary Home SN Mishra, Principal Secretary to Chief Minister and Tourism Faiz Ahmed Kidwai, Principal Secretary Public Health Engineering and Medical Education Sanjay Shukla and other officials were present in the video conference.

The video conference was attended by all the Divisional Commissioners, District Collectors, Chief Executive Officers of Zila panchayats, Commissioner Municipal Corporation, Inspector General of Police, Deputy Inspectors General of Police, Superintendents of Police, Commandant Home Guards, Chief Medical and Health Officer and Civil Surgeon.

Title: Shadow Box Theatre Festival called off because of Corona
Article:
With the outbreak of Coronavirus the weeklong theatre festival Shadow Box Theatre Festival has been called off. The festival was scheduled from March 18 to March 22.

The theatre festival was organised by Shadow Theatre Group, Bhopal. The information was given through instagram and facebook handles. It was infomed that the festival will be rescheduled and will be informed through social media handles soon.

The theatre festival was a collage of poetry, plays, talk shows and more. On March 18 Dastangoi, on March 19, play Trinoyon, on March 20, play Nepathya Mein Shakuntala, on March 21, play Boo and on March 22, play Vladimir Ka Hero was scheduled to be staged.

Another session included Talk Sessions. On March 18 Girija Shakar's session, on March 21 Talk on Childer's Theatre by Dhanendra Kawade and Abhishek Garg, on March 22 Santosh Chaubey (Kahaniyo Ka Rangmanch) was scheduled.

Besides, Rang Sangeet was scheduled on March 19, A non verbal act Nal-Jal was scheduled on March 22. A poets meet was also scheduled on March 20.

The same plays and sessions will be re-scheduled. It is noteworthy that poets, authors and playwrights were invited from across the country for Shadow Box Theatre Fest.

Title: Group exhibition showcasing art pieces of different Gond artists on display at Art Gallery
Article:
A group exhibition showcasing the art pieces of different Gond artists is on display at Art Gallery, Ustad Alauddin Khan Academy. The exhibition will remain on display till March 21.

It is to be noted that to commomerate Gond Art Year, a group painting exhibition on Gond Art is being put up at Art Gallery.

Artists like Durga Bai, Rani Parste, Santosh Maravi, Kala Bai, Anand Singh Shyam, Venkat Raman Shyam and more have displayed their works at the exhibition.

It is to be noted that these paintings are basically based on the Vastu and traditions of its area. The tribal people live with their tradition and define it in their creativity and all the paintings have distinctive features. Gond paintings portray the scenes, birds, animals and human faces on dark and vibrant colours. The paintings have brown or black base.

Gond paintings can best be described as ‘on line work’. The artist makes sure to draw the inner as well as outer lines with as much care as possible so that the perfection of the lines has an immediate effect on the viewer. Lines are used in such a way that it conveys a sense of movement to the still images. Dots and dashes are added to impart a greater sense of movement and increase the amount of detail.

Another very striking facet of Gond paintings is the use of bright vivid colours such as white, red, blue and yellow. The paints are usually derived naturally from objects such as charcoal, coloured soil, plant sap, leaves and even cow dung.

Title: inbrief
Article:
Commissions’ chairpersons get cabinet rank

Bhopal: Cabinet Minister status has been granted to chairpersons of State Women’s Commission, State Scheduled Castes Commission, State Scheduled Tribes Commission, State Backward Classes Commission and State Youth Commission in the State. Similarly, members of the State Women's Commission, the State Scheduled Castes Commission and the State Scheduled Tribes Commission have been given the status of Minister of State. Orders in this regard have been issued by the General Administration Department.

It may be noted that the State Government has recently appointed Shobha Ojha as Chairperson of State Women's Commission, Shri Gajendra Singh Rajukhedi, Chairperson of State Scheduled Tribes Commission, Anand Ahirwar Chairperson State Scheduled Castes Commission, JP Dhanopia Chairperson State Backward Classes Commission and Abhay Tiwari as Chairman of the State Youth Commission.

Similarly, Neena Singh, Jamuna Maravi, Shashi Rajput, Sangeeta Sharma and Sharmila S Moyde have been made members of the State Women’s Commission, Pradeep Ahirwar and Gurucharan Khare as members of State Scheduled Castes Commission and Gulab Uike and Heerasan Uike as members of State Scheduled Tribes Commission.

GAD issues order on promotion

Bhopal: The General Administration Department has issued instructions that as long as the matter of promotion is under consideration in the High Court, all departments should take action to amend their recruitment rules for giving promotions to State Government officials and employees like the State Administrative Service, Indian Administrative Service and Indian Police Service for higher posts. It may be noted that this decision was taken in a meeting of Ministers, officers and senior advocates held on February 8, 2020 under the chairmanship of Chief Minister Kamal Nath. On the initiative of General Administration Minister Govind Singh, Additional Chief Secretary General Administration KK Singh had issued instructions to all departments to take necessary action in this regard.

Chief Municipal Officer, Tarana, suspended

Bhopal: Commissioner, Urban Administration and Development, P Narhari, has suspended Banne Singh Solanki, Chief Municipal Officer, Municipal Council, Tarana, Ujjain district with immediate effect. This action has been taken against Solanki for being absent from office and negligent in the implementation of essential works and important schemes of the city Council.

During the suspension period, the headquarters of Solanki will be Divisional Office, Joint Director, Urban Administration and Development Ujjain division, Ujjain. During the suspension period Solanki will be entitled to receive sustenance allowance as per rules.

encroachment on Govt defence land on

Mhow: The encroachment on the several acres of government defence land is in full swing in Mhow defense estate area in form of several marriage gardens which are earning in lakhs per day on defense land.

Interestingly few days back the defense estate office

Mhow demolished small shops of snacks and refreshment of poor daily workers and left the big marriage gardens who earns in lakhs per day. The Pioneer in its November 18, 2019 edition had highlighted the names of illegal marriage gardens for which defense estate officer Neha Gupta told The Pioneer that he would issue notices for damage charges and demolition to the marriage garden owners but the action is still pending since months in the meanwhile some new marriage gardens have emerged.

Again while talking to The Pioneer DEO Neha Gupta told that action will be taken on the marriage gardens but it will take upto two weeks.

COVID-19 declared infectious for entire State

Bhopal: Novel Corona (COVID-19) has been declared as infectious disease for the entire State by the State Government. According to the notification issued by the Department of Public Health and Family Welfare, this action has been taken under Section 50 of the Madhya Pradesh Public Health Act 1949. Under Section 51 of this Act, it has been declared Notified Infectious Disease for the entire state.

Amount released for 46 Eklavya Schools

Bhopal: The amount paid to students studying in 46 Eklavya Model Residential Schools in 25 districts run by the Tribal Welfare Department has been increased from Rs 31 thousand 500 to Rs 47,860. This amount is given to the students for housing, food, uniform, medical and cultural activities.

It may be noted that 13,00 students are studying in 14 Eklavya schools of the state. Scholarship is of Rs 2,500 per month being provided to students studying in 123 specialised residential schools of the state. The process of recruitment for the post of Principal on deputation is in progress in these schools.

The last date for submission of applications for this has been extended from March 16 to March 31, 2020.

Title: House burgled at Neelbad, valuables taken away
Article:
Miscreants targeted a house in Neelbad and escaped with valuables worth Rs 2.5 lakh including Rs 1 lakh cash on Tuesday. Ratibad police started investigation.

Police said that the victim, JP Deep, along with his family, had gone to celebrate Holi and when he returned, the valuables were found burgled.

A complaint was lodged by the victim with the Ratibad police and in his complaint, he stated that he had gone to celebrate Holi at his village and when he returned in Tuesday the lock was found broken and valuables were found burgled.

On entering the house victim found that Rs 1 lakh cash and jewelry worth around Rs 1.5 lakh were burgled. The total loss in the burglary was claimed to be around Rs 2.5 lakh. The victim would provide the details of the jewelry after checking the burgled jewelry.

Based on the complaint after the preliminary investigation the police have registered a case under sections 457 and 380 of the IPC and have started further investigation.

Police have detained few suspects in the case but it was not ascertained that the miscreants have been narrowed down.

During the investigation, when the neighbours and locals were questioned regarding the burglary they expressed ignorance while the domestic help and security guards failed to provide any information.

Police have not any found any vital clue which could help in identifying the miscreants involved in the burglary by checking the CCTV cameras installed in the area and nearby areas.

Title: Handloom Expo 2020 begins at Bhopal Haat
Article:
This season, the fashion freaks of the city have a huge choice of varieties to look elegant. The Handloom Expo 2020 began at Bhopal Haat here from Wednesday wherein the fashionistas of the city can buy the best elegant dress for this festive season.

The artisans from across the country have come together with the best of the new-in trend and updated as well as regional attires for Bhopalites. The expo is all about various varieties of silk and cotton dresses. The expo will continue till March 30.

From ethnic wear to traditional silk dresses all are available at the handloom expo. Interestingly more than 20 designers and weavers are part of this year's exhibition. Artisans from six handloom weaving States including Karnataka, Bihar, Orissa, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Jammu and Kashmir, West Bengal and many others have displayted their works at the exhibition.
